title: On the Electrodynamics of Moving Bodies
subtitle: Special Theory of Relativity
summary: Einstein's groundbreaking paper that introduced the Special Theory of Relativity, revolutionizing our understanding of space, time, and motion.
keyEquationExplanation: Energy equals mass times the speed of light squared - showing mass and energy are interchangeable

sections.title: The Problem
sections.content: Classical physics couldn't explain why the speed of light appeared constant regardless of the observer's motion. This contradiction between Maxwell's equations and Newtonian mechanics needed resolution.

sections.title: The Revolutionary Postulates
sections.content:
1. The laws of physics are the same in all inertial reference frames
2. The speed of light in vacuum is constant (c = 299,792,458 m/s) for all observers, regardless of their motion or the motion of the light source

sections.title: Mind-Bending Consequences
sections.content:
• Time Dilation: Moving clocks run slower
• Length Contraction: Moving objects shrink in the direction of motion
• Relativity of Simultaneity: Events simultaneous in one frame aren't in another
• Mass-Energy Equivalence: E=mc² - mass can be converted to energy

sections.title: Real-World Applications
sections.content:
• GPS satellites must account for time dilation
• Particle accelerators rely on relativistic effects
• Nuclear power and atomic bombs use E=mc²
• Cosmic ray interactions in Earth's atmosphere

funFacts: Einstein was 26 years old and working as a patent clerk when he published this paper
The famous equation E=mc² wasn't in the original paper - it came in a follow-up paper months later
The paper had no footnotes or references to other scientists' work
It took years for the scientific community to fully accept these ideas

equations.name: Length Contraction
equations.explanation: Length (L') of a moving object contracts in the direction of motion

equations.explanation: Complete relativistic energy equation including momentum

title: The Foundation of the General Theory of Relativity
subtitle: General Relativity
summary: Einstein's masterpiece that describes gravity not as a force, but as the curvature of spacetime caused by mass and energy.
keyEquationExplanation: The Einstein Field Equations - showing how matter curves spacetime

sections.title: The Big Idea
sections.content: Gravity isn't a force pulling objects together. Instead, massive objects curve the fabric of spacetime itself, and objects follow the straightest possible paths (geodesics) through this curved spacetime.

sections.title: The Equivalence Principle
sections.content:
Einstein's key insight: You can't tell the difference between:
• Standing in a gravitational field on Earth
• Being in an accelerating rocket in deep space

This equivalence led him to realize gravity must be geometric, not a force.

sections.title: Predictions That Changed Physics
sections.content:
• Light bends around massive objects (gravitational lensing)
• Time runs slower in stronger gravitational fields
• Mercury's orbit precesses in a way Newton couldn't explain
• Gravitational waves ripple through spacetime
• Black holes can exist

sections.title: Modern Applications
sections.content:
• GPS systems must correct for both special AND general relativistic effects
• Gravitational wave detectors (LIGO) confirmed Einstein's 100-year-old prediction
• Black hole imaging relies on general relativity
• Cosmology and the expanding universe

funFacts: It took Einstein 10 years to develop general relativity after special relativity
The 1919 solar eclipse expedition confirmed light bending, making Einstein world-famous overnight
Einstein's equations predicted black holes, but he didn't believe they could actually exist
The equations are so complex that exact solutions are rare - most require supercomputers

title: On a Heuristic Point of View Concerning the Production and Transformation of Light
subtitle: Photoelectric Effect
summary: Einstein's Nobel Prize-winning work that proved light behaves as particles (photons), not just waves, founding quantum mechanics.
keyEquationExplanation: Energy of a photon equals Planck's constant times frequency

sections.title: The Mystery
sections.content:
When light hits certain metals, electrons are ejected. But classical wave theory couldn't explain why:
• Dim blue light ejects electrons, but bright red light doesn't
• Electron energy depends on light frequency, not intensity
• Electrons are ejected instantly, with no time delay

sections.title: Einstein's Quantum Leap
sections.content:
Einstein proposed light comes in discrete packets (quanta) called photons. Each photon carries energy E = hf, where h is Planck's constant and f is frequency.

When a photon hits an electron:
• If E > work function, electron escapes
• Excess energy becomes kinetic energy
• More photons = more electrons, not more energy per electron

sections.title: Revolutionary Implications
sections.content:
• Light has particle-like properties (wave-particle duality)
• Energy is quantized at the atomic level
• Founded quantum mechanics
• Explained atomic spectra and chemical bonds

sections.title: Modern Technology
sections.content:
• Solar panels convert photons to electricity
• Digital cameras use photoelectric sensors
• Photomultiplier tubes in medical imaging
• Quantum computing and cryptography

funFacts: Einstein won the Nobel Prize for THIS work, not relativity!
He called photons 'light quanta' - the term 'photon' came later
This paper was published in the same 'miracle year' (1905) as special relativity
Even Einstein was uncomfortable with the full implications of quantum mechanics

equations.explanation: Minimum frequency needed to eject electrons

title: On the Motion of Small Particles Suspended in a Stationary Liquid
subtitle: Brownian Motion
summary: Einstein's mathematical proof that atoms and molecules exist, by explaining the random jittering of particles in fluids.
keyEquationExplanation: Mean squared displacement equals 2 times diffusion coefficient times time

sections.title: The Puzzle
sections.content: In 1827, botanist Robert Brown observed pollen grains jittering randomly in water under a microscope. For decades, scientists debated: What causes this motion? Are atoms real?

sections.title: Einstein's Brilliant Solution
sections.content:
Einstein proved the jittering is caused by invisible water molecules constantly bombarding the pollen grains. He derived equations predicting:
• How far particles move over time
• How temperature affects motion
• The size of molecules

This provided the first direct evidence that atoms and molecules actually exist!

sections.title: The Mathematical Beauty
sections.content: Einstein used statistical mechanics to show that the random walk of particles follows predictable patterns. The average distance traveled grows with the square root of time, not linearly.

sections.title: Impact and Applications
sections.content:
• Proved atomic theory (some scientists still doubted atoms existed!)
• Founded statistical physics
• Explained diffusion processes
• Modern applications: drug delivery, pollution tracking, stock market models

funFacts: This was Einstein's PhD thesis topic - he got his doctorate in 1905
Jean Perrin won the Nobel Prize in 1926 for experimentally confirming Einstein's predictions
Einstein never actually observed Brownian motion himself
The same math describes stock prices, forest fires, and internet traffic
